text:
So very excited to be here
today to share with you what I've been working on.

So before I really
jump into things, I thought I would
give a sense of what

the style of work that really
gets me excited, which is really

about the potential to leverage
emerging technology to improve

people's lives, while working on
interesting technical problems. So this coincides pretty well
with the communities and topics

that I consider. So they being
autonomy, specifically, for roadways, intelligent
transportation systems,

and learning for
decisions and control. So I'm going to now
remind you of something

that we use every day. And, thus, it's easy to
take for granted sometimes, something that we actually rely
on for just a lot of our lives.

So roadways are--
you can think of them as the circulatory
system of the economy.

They bring producers
to markets, workers to jobs, students to
schools, sick to hospitals,
and so on, and so forth. So they're critical. They're a critical piece.

At the same time,
they're far from perfect. And so there is
a lot that we can do to improve these
in all dimensions.

So the approach that we've been
taking for the last 20 years, as to how to
improve roadways, is

what we might consider something
like autonomy-driven design. So this is the idea that if
you can achieve autonomy--

Let's figure out perception,
planning, common sense reasoning, social
orientation, altruism, and maybe a few other things.

And then we can use this to
make roadways more sustainable. And by more
sustainable, I'm going

to restrict the definition
here to mean that roadways are safer, cheaper, cleaner.

And it can mean a lot
of other things as well. So as you might know
from there not being

any of this in actual roadways,
this was harder than we thought.

So let me recap a bit as to this
phase of autonomy driven design,

where we are, why we thought
this was a good idea, and what we can learn from it. So I'm sure many of you
have seen this before.

This is the Gartner hype curve. This describes the life
cycle of a technology, which includes the hype
stage, which is

when expectations for this
technology are inflated.

So there have been
multiple waves of hype for roadway autonomy. This is not the first.

This is probably-- this
is perhaps not the last. But this started-- this
wave started and kicked off

with the DARPA Grand
Challenge and Urban Challenge, of which Stanford
has had an immense history,

around 2005. And something like
a decade later, we start seeing
articles of this flavor.

This is a business insider
piece titled wide adoption of self-driving cars could
be only five years away.

So that didn't happen. A few years later, we had
the very unfortunate Uber self-driving car crash,
which struck and killed

a pedestrian, Elaine Herzberg. Causation or correlation,
I don't know. But this coincides
with a lot of the dip

than in the hype for
autonomous driving. Here we are today.

Still somewhere in this area. So roadway autonomy
has been through a lot.

And I want to recap why we
thought this was a good idea, and, again, what we
can learn from it.

The rationale for
roadway autonomy really does have its merits. So let's review this. The first motivation is safety.

So there are something
like 43,000 fatalities on US roadways. This is from 2021.

And there's this very
famous study from NISHTHA that concludes that about that
human error is involved in about

94% of these fatalities. So it is very hard to conceive
of an approach that would really

get us to zero deaths
without removing the human from the equation. So that's argument number one.

The second one is cost. So I don't know about you, but I
could use a 25th hour in my day.

A bunch of studies conclude that
Americans spent about an hour on the road. So one thing we could do is we
could all hire a taxi drivers.

That's very expensive. So travel time is by far
the largest component of cost in the transport
of people and goods

throughout the country. So autonomy could
potentially do something about that cost factor.

Third being the environment. And there are many more along
the lines of externalities.

So the transportation sector is
the largest contributing sector of greenhouse gas emissions
in the US, at this point,

at around 29%. And a vast majority of
these emissions, about 80%

are on roadways. So autonomy could
enable all efficient use

of vehicles that could
accelerate electrification. It could enable
sharing of vehicles, potentially, integration
with transit.

It could smooth traffic flow. It could help everyone use
the right size of vehicles, platooning, so all
these benefits.

So this was the reasoning. Let's build autonomy. And then we get
sustainable roadways.

The question is in the premise. It's not really clear
if this first piece is technologically ready.

So I'm going to argue
that sustainable roadways, at this point, having given
this a few decades of time

to develop, may require
a different approach. So for lack of a
better term, I'm

going to call this
use driven design. So the way this works
is, let's consider what we want to do in terms
of improving roadways.
And then let's design for that. So the logic is a bit flipped.

Let's start with sustainable
roadways on the left-hand side. And ask, what do we need in
order to enable the sustainable

roadways? And if, indeed, it
requires autonomy, then we're stuck
where we started out.

But if not, then we might be
able to make some progress. So it's a question of
autonomy is sufficient, but,

is it necessary? So I'm going to look at a
relaxed notion of autonomy.

And, specifically, I'm going
to look at the coordination of vehicles. This is something
that autonomy enables.

But, potentially, you don't
need all of autonomy to do this. So you might need planning. You might need some
degree of altruism,

a few other components. But you don't need the
full, full, full thing that is what we
think of as autonomy.

And the question is,
does the coordination of vehicles by itself
enable us to achieve

more sustainable roadways? If so, then the full
thing of autonomy was sufficient,
but not necessary.

And if not-- This is what this talk
is going to focus on, this coordination of vehicles.

So the rest of the talk
is going to be as follows. I'm going to talk one
at a time regarding

how intelligent
coordination of vehicles could achieve cheaper mobility,
cleaner mobility, safer

mobility, and so on. So along the way, there's
going to be a bit of a detour,

because these
intelligent coordination problems, these
multi-agent control problems are annoyingly
hard to solve.

And so we also had to
take a detour in order to improve on these
methods a bit.

So first, I'm going to jump
into the first part, which is on cheaper ways to achieve
intelligent coordination

for sustainable roadways. So this is joint work
done with my students Jung-Hoon, Sirui, and Mayuri,
and my collaborator Roy

Dong at UIUC. So this has a couple pieces. But I'm going to focus on
the average case performance

analysis. And I'm just going to touch a
little bit on the worst case stability analysis.

So a very cheap way
to coordinate vehicles is to simply give
drivers an app. This is like much less of a
requirement than full autonomy.

If you look at this in
the spectrum of the SAE levels of autonomy from 0
to 5, with zero, being fully

manually driven cars to level
five, fully autonomous cars. we can think of this as
something like level 0.5.

So the car doesn't even have to
have any level of intelligence. We just need a smart
phone in the car. And this we might think
of as probably the lowest

cost near term form of autonomy
that we could possibly have. And the question is
then, what can this do?

So what we know from my
work as well as others is that with level
five full autonomy,

we can achieve system
level improvements even with a fraction of cars that are
equipped with this level five

autonomy. We can analyze these
traffic scenarios and see that by optimizing
a fraction of cars,

we can see system level
improvements in terms of speed and throughput.

So this is sufficient. Level five is sufficient. Is it necessary? And the way we can
analyze this is

we can slice this along
the spectrum and ask, is level four sufficient? Is level one
sufficient and so on?

And so we're just going to go
all the way to the other end, because it's appealing that
it is also a very low cost.

So this brings us to
the problem of what

we call coarse-grained control. So the question
is, to what extent can guided human drivers
achieve the same kind

of traffic optimizing behavior
of autonomous vehicles? You can think of guidance as
a dynamic speed limit sign.

That's potentially
even personalized to individual vehicles
and drivers, or similarly,

on the acceleration side. This is not a command. This is a speed limit
the driver can still

maintain safety and whatnot. So we consider this very simple
model of coarse-grained control

just piece-wise
constant guidance. So some speed held for
some time, another speed held for some time.

And we're going to keep
that time constant. So this is also known as
zero order holds with a hold

length of some delta seconds. And the goal is to design
these coarse-grained control laws, pi sub delta.

And the question is, how
coarse can these instructions be such that we still achieve
traffic optimizing behavior?

So we can see that
there's a whole length that we can consider different
problems with hold lengths

like very high frequency. Hold lengths like 0.1
seconds, all the way to instructions that
update every 40 seconds.

And so on one end
of the spectrum, you have our model of
an autonomous vehicle. Instructions that are changing
so quickly a human cannot

respond, up to a point, where
it's within the realm of work that instructions that humans
could potentially follow.

And so we're just borrowing
from some human factors research that eight seconds is
in the ballpark of what

humans can respond to. And we're engaging in-- we're designing some
user studies now to confirm it for our setting.

So the specific setting
or to be a bit more concrete about
the setting, let's consider a traffic scenario,
different networks,

where a fraction Ro of
vehicles are guided. And 1 minus RHO are not guided. And just recall, all the
vehicles are human driven now.

The guided vehicles
follow some actions from this learned
controller pi sub

delta, where the action
updates every delta time. Whereas, the unguided
vehicles follow instructions

according to a
conventional driving model. So keep in mind, now, that the
guidance type, the hold length,

and the traffic scenario, each
is its own multi-agent control

problem. So we solve this family
of control problems by just independently learning
these control laws using

deep reinforcement learning. And in some cases, we can
analyze the stability as well of the coarse-grained system.

So I'm going to jump
right to the results. And then go back and talk a
little bit about the methods. So let's look at
this model highway.

So this is a circular track. This is the cart
pole of traffic. So it's a simple
environment, where

you would want your stuff
to work before looking at something more complex. So a few observations
are nice here.

So the coarse-grained
guidance and zero order hold, actually, coincides
well with what's called sampled data systems.

And so there is a
body of theory that's used to analyze these systems. And so, in particular, these
Lyapunov-Krasovskii functionals

actually allows us to
derive sufficient conditions for system stability for
simple systems like this.

So we can gain some
intuition on whether or not the system should
completely fall apart

from a stability standpoint. Now, on the empirical side,
this is an easy problem

in a particular sense. There is a fixed
velocity that is optimal. So in principle, you could hold
whatever length you want to.

So here, we have the
hold length on the x-axis and the performance
on the y-axis. So, again, on this
end, we have the AV.

On this end, we have
more human-like driving. So we expect the performance
to decrease as the whole length

increases. But in this case, we should
expect a straight line. So we have the optimal
performance here,

which is better than
some baseline here. And what we see
here is that, yes, there is a constant
velocity that can

maintain the speed throughout. However, when we issue some
acceleration-based guidance,

what we see is,
actually, it's still possible to do almost just as
well, even up to 40 seconds.

However, when we apply vanilla
reinforcement learning, we see this hint of brittleness.

We see that it's actually very,
very jagged this training curve. And keep in mind that the
only difference between, say,

this problem, and this problem
is just the hold length. The scenario is the same. The guidance type is the same.

So it's a very, very small
change to the environment. And training with reinforcement
learning with our hyper

parameter tuning and
whatnot, it was actually rather disappointing for us.

And so this,
actually, motivated us to develop a method, which we're
calling the temporal transfer

method. And this is the idea that
this leverages the idea that these problems are
more or less the same.

The only difference
is this hold length. So the idea is that for
some target hold length,

we should be able
to find a policy. We should be able to
solve a different problem. And then if it's successful,
transfer the result

to this problem. So we're going to
leverage two ideas here. One is that these--

recall, these problems are
all more or less the same. But the coarser the
problem, the easier it is to solve, because the
shorter the effective horizon.

There are fewer decisions
you have to get right for the same amount of time. So easier to solve.

You can think of that
as reducing the variance in training. However, because the
instructions are coarser,

this may introduce some
bias, in particular, that the optimal
performance could be lower.

So what we're exploiting here
is that there's some sweet spot. There's some sweet spot where
the performance is still

just as good or
good enough that we can identify that sweet
spot is easier to train. And then we can transfer to the
target location-- target hold

length. So we can solve this using a
stochastic form of binary search to identify this ideal
source hold length.

So using these
ideas, we can then look at more
sophisticated settings. So, for instance, this
highway ramp setting.

Now, we see the behavior that
we expect that on one end, we have high performance
from the autonomous vehicle--

I should say, red is
without our method. Blue is with our method. So we see higher performance
above some baseline.

And that performance degrades
as the whole length increases, which we expect. But still, for quite a bit
of what we understand now

to be the human
compatible region, there is still significant
improvement over the baseline.

So what we conclude here is that
the coarse-grained guidance does preserve benefits from
autonomous vehicles in terms

of speed, fuel throughput across
a variety of traffic scenarios. The implication is that
these guided human drivers

could enable near-term,
low-cost autonomy benefits. And that while vanilla
reinforcement learning

is brittle to even these
very small changes, this temporal
transfer method can improve the
reliability of training

these coarse-grained
control laws. Yes? So if people do not follow the
guidance, have you studied--

Robustness to how much people-- Yeah. We're doing that work now. We don't have it yet. But yeah we're
doing that work now.

It is important to factor
in the robustness aspect.

Maybe a related question. What are your thoughts on
the trade-off between giving

this guidance to
drivers and the extent to which it can draw attention
away from the main driving task,

if they're thinking, I should
speed up or I should slow down. Are you worried
about that thing? I think there's a lot more that
needs to be explored there.

That's definitely
outside of my wheelhouse. What we can do is we can
actually analyze the resulting

trajectories and whether
those trajectories are safer, according to these
surrogate safety measures. So that's something
that we are starting

to do in a slightly
different context.

Do you think the time horizon
is dependent on the environment? For example-- Yeah.

Absolutely. The time horizon should be
dependent on the environment. And, also, we are also
thinking about making

it adaptive like based
on the conditions, the real-time conditions. Right now, it's just constant.

So this is a very simple
model that we could analyze. We have one axis,
where we can just do

a first pass at this problem. I think there's a ton more
that can be done here. Good.

So we're going to-- this brittleness of
reinforcement learning was very disappointing to us.

And so we took a detour to try
to understand this problem. And so, in particular,
this is a couple--

it's a couple lines of
work where we are asking, is it just us?

Are we failing to use
reinforcement learning? Or is it specific to our problem
or is it reinforcement learning?

We want to tease apart
what the challenge was. And then some ideas as to
how to go about resolving

this brittleness. So this is the brittleness
that we observed. And what we basically did--

I'm going to be
very brief on this. But we, basically,
also identified brittleness of deep RL
in existing benchmarks.

So staying close to home,
there is this benchmark on traffic signal control,
controlling signals, not cars.

And this benchmark includes both
classical techniques as well as

learning-based
techniques, reinforcement learning-based techniques. And what we have
done is we modeled--

basically, you can think
of the previous work as like, OK, when you vary
the environment a little bit, the method no longer works.

So we vary the
environment a little bit based on an actual distribution
of traffic intersections

with our partners Utah
Department of Transportation. So we modeled the
160 intersections

from Salt Lake City. And then all we're doing is
we're taking these methods, and we're re-evaluating
on this set

of natural variations of this
task of traffic signal control. We're retraining on each
individual intersection.

So we're not doing
generalization. We're testing the
robustness of the algorithm.

What we find is that on a
ranking from best to worst, while the reported was reported
in the original benchmark is

that these learning-based
methods outperform the most prominent fixed--

prominent classical technique
of just fixed time control. When we're evaluate on
the natural variations,

the fixed time control
and the classical methods together outperform all
of the learning methods.

And there's no specific pattern
in what kinds of intersections

the methods are failing in. And I think that
requires further work. So for us, this is not great
news for reinforcement learning.

But it also tells us that
it might not just be us. We also then looked at this for
the popular control benchmarks

like this half cheetah and this
pendulum and this cart pole. And we find that by
varying the length

of the pole and the gravity
coefficients and whatnot, you don't see as drastic
of a flip in terms of like,

we should not use
learning anymore. But we find flips in
terms of which methods

are considered best-- which reinforcement learning
methods are considered best.

So it's not just us. This makes us want to throw
reinforcement learning out the window. But we do like
some aspects of it.

So, for instance, the
learning-based methods are motivated by how rigid
model-based methods can

be to the assumptions of
the underlying problem. And so what we would really-- I just want methods that work.

So it's very natural to
ask, how about methods that try to incorporate
the best of both worlds?

So more hybrid methods that can
both leverage the known problem structure in a
model-based sense,

but also provide flexibility
for the difficult to model aspects like model free. And I think there's a ton
of work in this space.

But what we need is we need this
for our vehicle coordination problems. So with this, we
need some data set

of problems with
natural variations. And we are painstakingly
creating some by modeling it
with Salt Lake City

and by looking at
these problems. But there isn't an image
net that you can just download for studying this
problem systematically.

And that's a huge issue here. So what we're doing
is we're faking a data set by looking to
discrete optimization, which

has documented over decades,
natural variations of problems,

including certain kinds of
vehicle coordination problems. So this area is
a new one for me,

but very compelling
and very interesting. So consider this problem of
the vehicle routing problem. This is like Amazon's
package delivery problem

that they solve every day. And Uber's problem and whatnot. So there are a lot of
vehicle routing problems

that are practical today. This problem has been studied
for at least 60 years. And this is a nice tree
of almost the evolution

of this problem. As the world evolves, we
realize, sometimes, the vehicles have capacities. Sometimes, there
are time windows

on when I need to
deliver the packages. Sometimes, the
vehicles are electric. And so these variations
of these problems

have emerged over
the last 60 years. So we have this data set
of natural variations that we didn't have to
painstakingly come up with.

But these are still open and
active research problems. So what we can do is then
we can use this as a basis

for trying to design
methods that are more robust to natural variations.

What we're going to
do is we're going to leverage an already
effective strategy for many of these problems, especially,
at large scale, which is called

large neighborhood search. So the key idea here is that
large problems can often be decomposed into small problems.

And what large
neighborhood search does is it basically iteratively
seeks a better solution by re-optimizing sub-problems.

So here's a big problem. We identify a sub-problem. We solve it. We presume that we can
solve a small problem.

But we can't solve a big
problem, or, at least, we can improve a small problem. And then we take the solution to
that small problem, put it back

into the big problem. And then we iterate. And what is typically done
is that the sub-problem

is selected randomly or using a
heuristic that's then customized for the particular application.

So what we're going
to do is we're going to learn the promising
sub-problem or sub-problems

to select. And I'm going to skip
over all the details. There's a transformer. It's a regression
problem and whatnot.

And skip right to the results. So for the most commonly-- most
widely studied form of vehicle

routing problem, which is the
capacitated vehicle routing problem, fairly large problem,
2,000 nodes or cities,

we can see that a learning
approach can, basically, cut in half the solve time.

So it can be twice as fast as
random sub-problem selection. Largely research itself
is already very powerful.

It already gives
like a 10 times speed up over not using large
neighborhood search.

And then what we can do is we
can use that same algorithm. And we can train it, again,
on variations of the vehicle

routing problem, as long as you
have big problems that can be decomposed into small problems. And we look specifically
at CVRP with time windows,

as well as with
pickup and delivery. And we, again, see speed up. So what's happening here is some
implicit learning of a selection

strategy that customized to
these different variations that, at least, outperforms
the random selection.

So what we learn is that
deep reinforcement learning fails to be robust to these
natural variations, including

very small variations, like,
the whole length of a problem, as well as the layout of
the signalized intersection,

the standard control benchmarks. And that this algorithm, which
we call learn to delegate, which

is this learning guided
large neighborhood search, is more robust to natural
variations of the vehicle

routing problem as compared
to random selection. So we're extending this
idea now to a variety

of settings, which includes
different applications. We're looking at the
multi-agent pathfinding problem in warehouse
automation in collaboration

with Amazon Robotics. We're looking at different
sub-problem types. So rather than-- which specific
sub-problem to improve,

which type of
sub-problem to improve, as well as different
algorithm backbones, like branch-and-cut for solving
mixed integer linear programs

in collaboration with MathWorks. So now, I'm going to go back to
the main theme of sustainable

roadways. And look at how we can use
intelligent coordination for cleaner roadways.

This is the biggest project
I've ever undertaken. And it's still ongoing. And it's split into
modeling pieces and control

pieces, which will be evident. So let me remind you
that we urgently need to decarbonize transportation.

And it is the largest
contributing sector. So what I'm going
to try to exploit

here is that
traffic signals, you can think of them
as a safety device.

We need them for safety. But they induce stop and go
all the time and, basically, everywhere.

So about half of driving is
near signalized intersections. And this back of the
envelope calculation,

I found very helpful, when I
was designing this problem. But keep in mind, this is
very back of the envelope.

I take a recent survey for
how much emissions can you reduce by controlling cars
to mitigate emissions.

And I did a very
coarse meta-analysis. I took the plus/minus 1 standard
deviation of all the studies

reported in this survey. And it gives me 6% to
28% of CO2 emissions

is potentially avoidable. If you're optimistic, so
let's take the upper range. This says that about 15% of
CO2 could just not be used, not
be emitted. It's not doing productive work. So what does this look like?

Just demonstrating the idea. So with fixed-time
traffic control, you have quite a bit of
queuing at the intersection.

Cars come to a complete stop. When they come to
a complete stop, they have to fully
re-accelerate. Alternatively, if you
do some kind of what's

called eco-driving, you
can guide the cars in a way that when they get
to the intersection,

the intersection is green, they
didn't come to a complete stop, they may be slowed,
but they don't have to re-accelerate from stopped.

And that's where the
emissions gain comes from.

The research question here is,
would coordinating vehicles to reduce the CO2
at intersections

actually move the needle on
climate change mitigation goals? Maybe, it's a good idea. But maybe, it's very niche in
terms of where it is useful.

So this was a curiosity
to me, because when I started looking at this--

this is actually
called eco-driving at signalized intersections. It's a bit of a mouthful. But there are some 50 papers
on this topic already starting

from a decade ago. But we don't see any
of it in practice. And the question is, why not? Is it not worth doing?

Is it just not very effective? Is this a topic of
academic interest? Or is it a missed opportunity?

So the goal of this project
is to investigate not how to eco-drive.

A lot of the papers that--
a lot of the literature focuses on the more
detailed aspects of like, for this intersection,
for this kind of equipment,

Is it worth doing? We are interested in, thus,
what is the expected improvement

of eco-driving over
possible driving scenarios, the expectation. So what fun is that as I
was doing literature review,

this first reference here
is titled eco-driving, an overlooked climate change
initiative published in 2010.

This is, actually,
referencing highways. And, coincidentally,
actually, in cars there often

are these eco-driving
modes for highway driving. And it would be amazing
if there is an analog then

for the other half of driving. So the central
challenge of this work

is, basically, how
diverse the scenarios are. So we can look at first just
the diversity of intersections.

Every intersection has
a different numbers of approaches, different numbers
of lanes, different turning

restrictions. And so just the intersections
layouts themselves, these are all
factors that affect

eco-driving effectiveness. So we have to consider
this family of scenarios.

And this is just the ones that
I can picture very easily. There are additional
ones, such as the slope of the roadway, which,
obviously, would affect

eco-driving, the weather
conditions, the travel demand, vehicle types
and age, and all this.

So this is the
central challenge. Looking at the literature,
the first challenge

is, basically, that eco-driving
controller design has really focused on specific settings.

So there's no known approach
that can simultaneously handle this whole large
family of considerations.

There's also no
known approach that will scale to what we
end up with is millions

of different scenarios. So we take a multitask
deep reinforcement

learning approach, which I'll
get into more detail later. The second challenge,
which is really unfortunate

is that large scale
modeling of traffic has really focused on
highways, at least, in ways that are available
to academic researchers.

And so we need to,
actually, do the modeling of the urban traffic, the
driving that's actually

near signalized
intersections, as well as other eco-driving factors.

So we do this modeling. It's a huge effort. And in order to
do this at scale--

because keep in mind, we're
still doing a rough analysis. This is not for
implementation tomorrow.

In order to do this
at scale, we leverage OpenStreetMap, which is great. But if any of you have
used it, you, also,

know how terrible it is. So it's an amazing resource. But almost all of the
attributes are missing.

So most of the speed
limits are not-- most of the lane lengths
and turn configurations,

and all of this stuff
is just not there. And so we devised a data
imputation framework

to impute many of the
missing quantities. It's not perfect. But it is much better than
just not having the quantities.

This is only the static aspect
of what needs to be modeled. There are also non-static
aspects, such as,

for instance, the percentage of
vehicles that are being guided, the weather conditions, the
season, the actual travel

demand, and whatnot. Putting this together,
this gives us about 1.5 million scenarios.

And just to give you a sense,
this 27,000 intersections

is about 10% of the signalized
intersections in the country. And we chose the locations
based on high emitting areas,

as well as data availability. So this is also not everything. There's a very extensive
modeling effort

that I'm not going to belabor. Here, I have highlighted
just the aspects

actually, allowed
us to actually do this project as a
small academic team, is that many of the
non-static aspects

are actually already captured
by an industry standard model maintained by the
environmental protection agency.

So the EPA MOVES model
captures, for instance, what is the emissions of a
vehicle of a different age,

driving on a road of
a particular slope of a particular type at
a particular humidity

and temperature? So all of this detail is really
well-detailed in this model.

This is an excellent tool. Its main challenge for
us is, again, the scale,

because we're working
with a million scenarios. We computed that.

It would take us about
nine compute years to analyze these scenarios
by directly using the tool.

But what underlies the tool are
emissions models, which are, actually, continuous functions.

And so we engage in this
project to basically reverse engineer this EPA MOVES
model, and, basically, build--

we learned surrogate models
by fitting neural networks to this tool and extracted
the data to do this.

So this allowed us
to scale this up. So now, on to the control part. We're just going to optimize the
acceleration of the vehicles.

The vehicles around
us can lane change. But just to keep the problem
a little bit more tractable,

the guided vehicles
are only going to be optimizing
the acceleration for the eco-driving purpose.

So now, we do our multi-task
reinforcement learning. What does this mean? So every traffic scenario, every
one of the million scenarios

is a task. And when we train, we
sample for each rollout. We sample a new task,
a new traffic scenario.

And we add it to our-- we use
that data to train our policy. In order to make this
not totally silly,

we provide not only the
vehicles observations. But we also provide some
information about that task

to the input of
the neural network. We use very standard training
practices, otherwise.

So standard algorithms,
standard training protocols for this shared parameter
multi-agent setting.

Something that's non-standard is
that the reward function design is really important, given the
brittleness of reinforcement

learning. So we have several
works that are just focused on designing
this reward function.

This, itself, doesn't work
well, because very reasonably, having one policy work
over a million scenarios

is a tall order. So we extend this just a
little bit to something that we are calling
multi-multitask reinforcement

learning, which is multitask
reinforcement learning on a partition of the space. This partition is
heur-- is designed

based on domain knowledge. We end up with something
like seven policies. So seven partitions,
which is still

much less than the
original set of scenarios.

We're just partitioning
based on the number of lanes and the number of phases
in the traffic signal.

So now, on to the results. So the analysis here
is for Salt Lake City.

We're still crunching the
numbers on the other ones. But what we see, if
everyone is adopting this,

we see something like close
to a 11% reduction in fuel. If we're comfortable just
scaling this to the country--

so we assume that Salt Lake
City's intersections are representative of the country--

we get something like 1.5%
reduction in US level CO2.

So what does this mean to you? I, for a while, didn't know. I tried very hard to
find a reference point.

And a gold standard that I
found is from the venture fund

initiatives that can achieve-- that could that-- has
the potential to achieve 1% global greenhouse
gas emissions reduction.

So this is in that ballpark,
which is, to me, very exciting.

I can also say that at
around 20% adoption, we see about 0.4%
reduction in CO2.

And this 20% gives us
about 28% of the benefit.

So there's some non-linearity. And the intuition there is
that if some vehicles are eco-driving, the
vehicles behind them,

even if they're not
doing it themselves, might benefit as well. So we find that eco-driving
at signalized intersections

could, potentially,
substantially, contribute to transportation
decarbonisation. As part of this work, we
did extensive modeling

of urban traffic to fill
a gap in traffic modeling beyond highways. And we developed these
neural surrogates

for this industry
standard emissions model. And this, actually,
we found later

to be of potential high interest
to air quality researchers, because this tool is
the bread and butter

for these researchers. But there's also a very
high learning curve for this MOVES model, like,
maybe, one or two months

to learn how to use this. And so, potentially,
easing the access to this. And then, finally, this
multi-multi-task reinforcement

learning, actually, allowed
us to scale up the analysis to a million plus scenarios.

So then I'll talk

to be such an interesting area,

especially, really looking
at this for roadways. So this is work that was
just published, actually,

one or two weeks ago done
with my two students. Let me talk about why the
safer challenge is so hard.

The safer challenge
is really hard, because the bar is actually
really, really high.

Humans are just incredibly safe. So this is the
statistic for the US. There's about one fatality
every 80 million miles.

This is huge. This is eight nines of
reliability in terms of failure free miles.

This is eight nines
after the decimal point in terms of this probability. For reference, AWS is
at about two nines.

My roomba is at about one nine. And what about for
autonomous driving?

So here's a reference
point that we have. Waymo, over the last 10 years,

They've driven that much. It's really hard to put

So without some

which brings in-- which takes

Its record puts us at 10 nines,

But there are no autonomous

We're going to bring
in some of these ideas. So let's bring these ideas
from air traffic control down to dense roadway traffic.

Roadways are much more
dense than the open skies. And the idea here-- the
central idea is let's

complement the
autonomous capabilities of vehicles with
remote supervision from expert operators.

So let's not give autonomy
full responsibility. Let's also not
give infrastructure the full responsibility.

Let's see if we can get
the best of both worlds. So I'll look in a very
specific question right now.

So the question is, right now,
we do have A operator for A car. So it's like a 1 to 1 deal.

Imagine that you were
to take this operator and put them, him/her
into a call center,

basically, with
a steering wheel. Everything's perfect. Communication is perfect. Sensing is perfect.

So let's make all the
clean assumptions. The question is, in principle,
how many operators would you need to supervise
your fleet safely
at the reliability of humans-- at human now?

If it's 1 to 1 still,
that's not good. We just incurred additional
costs of all the communication

infrastructure and whatnot. So this is the question. As the AV fleet size grows,
how does the supervision scale?

So this is the scalability
of supervision problem. So we modeled this
using a queuing model.

So we can think of
arrivals to this queue as risky events that
need to be supervised.

And we have some
number of operators M that can supervise these. And we're interested
in the probability

that there are so many risky
events that arrive that there aren't enough operators. So what you can model this as
is a queue without a buffer.

So the buffer is exactly the
size of the number of operators. So if any new risky
event arrives,

it does not receive service. So effectively, we're
interested in the probability

of service loss. That's the probability
that the system already has M risky events.

And reliability-- you can think
of as 1 minus, this piece of M.

And then now, we can set that
to our eight nines or something.

So, specifically, we're
going to look at the most-- the closest to practical
setting for autonomous driving,

which is highways. We're specifically going to
look at a dangerous maneuver on highways, which is merging.

We're looking at merging on. You can also think
of it as merging off. So the first thing to
observe is that we're

going to assume that
once on the highway, the car can drive
safely by itself. So we're just looking at merge
conflicts are risky events.

So the first thing to observe
is that you don't always need to supervise the vehicle. If there's no merge
conflict-- sorry.

So if there's no merge
conflict, then there's no need to supervise. And we're going to determine
whether there might

be a merge conflict using
conservative worst case forward reachability, giving
the operator enough time

to understand the scenario. So in the interest
of time, I'm going to be very brief on the details.

The question is, what happens
when AV adoption grows? So intuitively,
more adoption means

there are more cars that
need to be supervised. So reliability goes down. When there are
more AVs, you also

have more AVs that can
sense the environment and communicate everyone's
trajectories and whatnot. So the reliability goes
back up at some point.

These are these dipped curves. The even more interesting
thing is, as you have more AVs, these AVs can start
to coordinate.

If you have two AVs
approaching the merge point, and they're both AVs, one
can just slow down and just

let the other one go. They don't have to collide, if
that was the planned trajectory. And as you have more
AVs, the probability

that it's two AVs that are
merging at the same time becomes higher. So these reliability curves for
the same number of operators

get shifted up with this
kind of coordination. And what we find through
some numerical examples-- we didn't cherry pick this.

But we also didn't
explore this extensively-- is that it could make something
like a six orders of magnitude difference in terms
of reliability

for a fixed number of operators. This is a particular
setting that where

50 supervisors achieves the
eight nines of reliability. Whereas, without cooperation,
it's at like 99%.

And this setting
corresponds to a scaling of about 42 operators-- sorry, 42 vehicles per operator.

And keep in mind that the
original-- the status quo is this 1 to 1.

That's all I wanted to say about
this first foray into safety. I'm finding this to be
such an interesting area.

There's so much more to be done. This is, to our knowledge, the
first queuing theoretic model

for supervision and coordination
of autonomous vehicles. And I think it's a really
interesting concept

to start thinking about these
relaxed notions of autonomy enabling a richer design
space for safer roadways.
